articles.headline: Fed Officials Say a September Rate Increase Is Still on the Table
articles.snippet: Economic conditions will govern any decision, the officials emphasize, though continued market volatility would make a move less likely.
articles.abstract: Economic conditions will govern any decision, the officials emphasize, though continued market volatility would make a move less likely.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — The Federal Reserve will give serious consideration to raising its benchmark interest rate in mid-September, particularly if volatility subsides in financial markets, a number of Fed officials said Friday.

articles.headline: Bitcoin Technology Piques Interest on Wall St.
articles.snippet: Financial firms are looking at the network and software that make it possible for Bitcoin to move around the world instantly and inexpensively.
articles.abstract: Financial firms are looking at the network and software that make it possible for Bitcoin to move around the world instantly and inexpensively.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most people still think of Bitcoin as the virtual currency used by drug dealers and shadowy hackers looking to evade the authorities.

articles.headline: Labor Board Ruling on Joint Employers Leaves Some Companies Scratching Their Heads
articles.snippet: Some fear the decision, which is likely to face legal challenges, could threaten the business model of staffing agencies, subcontractors and franchise operators.
articles.abstract: Some fear the decision, which is likely to face legal challenges, could threaten the business model of staffing agencies, subcontractors and franchise operators.
articles.lead_paragraph: A National Labor Relations Board ruling that could significantly change the relationship between companies and their subcontractors and between franchise operators and their franchisees has businesses in those industries scrambling to understand the ramifications.

articles.headline: A Passion for Hurling, the All-Ireland Game
articles.snippet: Hurling can be likened to a mash-up of lacrosse, field hockey and baseball, but in truth, it is a game all its own.
articles.abstract: Hurling can be likened to a mash-up of lacrosse, field hockey and baseball, but in truth, it is a game all its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: KINVARA, Ireland — Thirty men battle on a deep-green field, each one wielding what looks like a field hockey stick moonlighting as a broken oar. They chase a ball that fits snug in the hand, sometimes balancing it on their sticks as they run, sometimes swinging the sticks in midsprint to arc the ball toward a goal’s uprights.

articles.headline: Europe’s Halting Response to Migrant Crisis Draws Criticism as Toll Mounts
articles.snippet: The escalating death toll has highlighted the bloc’s failure to quit squabbling and come up with a unified plan for a crisis months in the making.
articles.abstract: The escalating death toll has highlighted the bloc’s failure to quit squabbling and come up with a unified plan for a crisis months in the making.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The daily toll among refugees and migrants desperately trying to reach Europe — 71 suffocated in a truck in Austria and 150 drowned off Libya this week — has dramatically underscored the European Union’s scattered, halting response to increasing waves of asylum seekers.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Alison Smale

articles.headline: Consumer Anxiety in China Undermines Government’s Economic Plans
articles.snippet: Middle-class Chinese are reining in spending amid the economic slowdown, damaging the ruling party’s hopes to push consumer spending as a new engine of growth.
articles.abstract: Middle-class Chinese are reining in spending amid the economic slowdown, damaging the ruling party’s hopes to push consumer spending as a new engine of growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — In recent days, an advice column has circulated widely on China’s most popular social media phone app. Titled “Guide on Safe Passage Through the Economic Crisis,” it is aimed at young Chinese urban professionals. Its nuggets of wisdom include: “Work hard at your job so you are the last to be laid off” and “In an economic crisis, liquidity is the number one priority.”

articles.headline: Young Hands in Mexico Feed Growing U.S. Demand for Heroin
articles.snippet: To meet the U.S. demand for heroin, Mexico is enlisting children to harvest opium. The money is too much to ignore for most, and the terrain is more manageable for those of slighter frame.
articles.abstract: To meet the U.S. demand for heroin, Mexico is enlisting children to harvest opium. The money is too much to ignore for most, and the terrain is more manageable for those of slighter frame.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL CALVARIO, Mexico — With her nimble hands, tiny feet and low center of gravity, Angelica Guerrero Ortega makes an excellent opium harvester.

articles.headline: Once a Pariah, Now a Judge: The Early Transgender Journey of Phyllis Frye
articles.snippet: Decades before Caitlyn Jenner, Phyllis Frye was grappling with bias, scorn and personal pain, and helping the transgender movement take shape.
articles.abstract: Decades before Caitlyn Jenner, Phyllis Frye was grappling with bias, scorn and personal pain, and helping the transgender movement take shape.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Nearly four decades before Caitlyn Jenner introduced herself to the world, Phyllis Randolph Frye came out as a transgender woman in a far less glamorous way. No Diane Sawyer, no Vanity Fair.

articles.headline: Prison Vendors See Continued Signs of a Captive Market
articles.snippet: As judges and policy makers debate sentencing changes to curb incarceration, those who sell goods to jails and prisons find little cause for concern.
articles.abstract: As judges and policy makers debate sentencing changes to curb incarceration, those who sell goods to jails and prisons find little cause for concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is there anything that cannot be turned into a weapon? Walk around the exhibitors’ hall at the conference of the American Correctional Association, held in Indianapolis in early August, and at some point the question will answer itself. Apparently, with enough malign intent and the right tools — a lighter, for instance — even disposable plates can be transformed into shivs.

articles.headline: U.S. Is Playing Catch-Up With Russia in Scramble for the Arctic
articles.snippet: With warming seas creating new opportunities at the top of the world, nations are scrambling over the Arctic. But Russia may be beating the United States to the punch.
articles.abstract: With warming seas creating new opportunities at the top of the world, nations are scrambling over the Arctic. But Russia may be beating the United States to the punch.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABOARD COAST GUARD CUTTER ALEX HALEY, in the Chukchi Sea — With warming seas creating new opportunities at the top of the world, nations are scrambling over the Arctic — its territorial waters, transit routes and especially its natural resources — in a rivalry some already call a new Cold War.

articles.headline: Owned by Union, Amalgamated Bank Gives Lift to the Left
articles.snippet: Amalgamated Bank has aggressively carved out a position as the left’s private banker, leveraging deep connections with the Democratic establishment.
articles.abstract: Amalgamated Bank has aggressively carved out a position as the left’s private banker, leveraging deep connections with the Democratic establishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Ready for Hillary, a pro-Hillary Rodham Clinton “super PAC,” wanted to take out a million-dollar loan five months before it planned to go out of business, it turned to a bank that was founded to guard the savings of New York City garment workers.

articles.headline: Behind Deadly Tianjin Blast, Shortcuts and Lax Rules
articles.snippet: Rui Hai International Logistics, whose warehouses were hit by the deadly explosions, has become a symbol of the high cost of rapid industrialization in a closed political system rife with graft.
articles.abstract: Rui Hai International Logistics, whose warehouses were hit by the deadly explosions, has become a symbol of the high cost of rapid industrialization in a closed political system rife with graft.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China — One partner was the son of a local police chief, the other an executive at a state-run chemicals firm. After meeting at a dinner party, they started a company here to handle the export of the most dangerous chemicals made in China, promising “outstanding service” and “good results.”
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs, Javier C. Hernández and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Soul-Searching in TV Land Over the Challenges of a New Golden Age
articles.snippet: With the number of shows approaching 400 this year, John Landgraf of FX Networks says the cluttered TV landscape is challenging viewers and the industry.
articles.abstract: With the number of shows approaching 400 this year, John Landgraf of FX Networks says the cluttered TV landscape is challenging viewers and the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Landgraf’s comments arrived like a thunderbolt.

articles.headline: Ahead of I.P.O., Univision Faces Bigger Rival Than Trump: Shifting TV Habits
articles.snippet: More troubling than its battle with Donald Trump, the Spanish-language broadcaster is dealing with a mixed bag of concerns — the same faced by most TV-based media companies — as it decides to go public.
articles.abstract: More troubling than its battle with Donald Trump, the Spanish-language broadcaster is dealing with a mixed bag of concerns — the same faced by most TV-based media companies — as it decides to go public.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump isn’t Univision’s only problem, or even its biggest.

articles.headline: Challenged on Left and Right, the Fed Faces a Decision on Rates
articles.snippet: An approaching action on interest rates is being closely watched as a broader debate divides liberals and conservatives over the management of the American economy.
articles.abstract: An approaching action on interest rates is being closely watched as a broader debate divides liberals and conservatives over the management of the American economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo. — Conservative activists who want the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates distributed chocolate coins in golden wrappers at the local airport last week as Fed officials arrived for their annual policy retreat.

articles.headline: Caste Quotas in India Come Under Attack
articles.snippet: Resentment has gelled into opposition to India’s version of affirmative action, a system of strict quotas that reserves nearly half of jobs for those from disadvantaged castes or tribes.
articles.abstract: Resentment has gelled into opposition to India’s version of affirmative action, a system of strict quotas that reserves nearly half of jobs for those from disadvantaged castes or tribes.
articles.lead_paragraph: AHMEDABAD, India — The resentment built slowly in Hardik Patel. It took root when he watched his younger sister lose out on a college scholarship because of India’s version of affirmative action, a system of strict quotas that reserves nearly half of government jobs and public college slots for those who come from disadvantaged castes or tribes.
articles.byline: By David Barstow and Suhasini Raj

articles.headline: Wall St. Policy Poses a Challenge for Presidential Candidates
articles.snippet: The opinions about Wall Street that are emerging from the presidential candidates suggest that the financial industry could face very different futures depending on which party wins the White House.
articles.abstract: The opinions about Wall Street that are emerging from the presidential candidates suggest that the financial industry could face very different futures depending on which party wins the White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even seven years after the financial crisis, Wall Street has lost none of its ability to stir partisan rancor.

articles.headline: Tools for Tailored Learning May Expose Students’ Personal Details
articles.snippet: Many technological tools used by schools are designed to customize learning, but concern is developing over the collection and use of data on individual students.
articles.abstract: Many technological tools used by schools are designed to customize learning, but concern is developing over the collection and use of data on individual students.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the efforts by state legislators to restrict the use of student data are any guide, the email addresses and search queries of the nation’s schoolchildren are a hot commodity.

articles.headline: As His Term Wanes, Obama Champions Workers’ Rights
articles.snippet: The administration has tried to get back protections for workers eroded by conservative activism and changes in the economy over 40 years.
articles.abstract: The administration has tried to get back protections for workers eroded by conservative activism and changes in the economy over 40 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With little fanfare, the Obama administration has been pursuing an aggressive campaign to restore protections for workers that have been eroded by business activism, conservative governance and the evolution of the economy in recent decades.

articles.headline: Protests in Iraq Bring Fast Promises, but Slower Changes
articles.snippet: The fight against corruption is also a battle against the legacy of the 2003 invasion by the United States, some demonstrators say.
articles.abstract: The fight against corruption is also a battle against the legacy of the 2003 invasion by the United States, some demonstrators say.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Surrounded by the clamor of protest — a sea of Iraqi flags, vendors selling coffee and melon drinks, protesters singing the national anthem and railing against politicians — two friends paused and described their dreams.

articles.headline: Migrant Crisis Tests Core European Value: Open Borders
articles.snippet: People flooding into Europe, and an inability to accommodate them in an organized way, may be starting to fray a commitment to erase old borders.
articles.abstract: People flooding into Europe, and an inability to accommodate them in an organized way, may be starting to fray a commitment to erase old borders.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — The desperate migrants and asylum seekers now flooding into Europe by the tens of thousands, and the inability so far to accommodate them in an organized way, may be starting to fray Europe’s commitment to erase old borders.
articles.byline: By Alison Smale and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Hotels Fight Back Against Sites Like Expedia and Priceline
articles.snippet: Hotel chains are using rewards points and benefits to encourage guests to book directly, while the industry fights a merger of Expedia and Orbitz.
articles.abstract: Hotel chains are using rewards points and benefits to encourage guests to book directly, while the industry fights a merger of Expedia and Orbitz.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, travelers have been drawn to online sites like Expedia, Travelocity, Orbitz and Priceline to find and reserve hotel rooms, flights and rental cars.
articles.byline: By Aaron M. Kessler and Julie Weed

articles.headline: Increase Taxes? Talk by Donald Trump Alarms G.O.P.
articles.snippet: Some influential party figures worry that Donald J. Trump’s suggestions that he would raise taxes in certain areas could catch on with rivals in the presidential race.
articles.abstract: Some influential party figures worry that Donald J. Trump’s suggestions that he would raise taxes in certain areas could catch on with rivals in the presidential race.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, Republicans have run for office on promises of cutting taxes and bolstering business to stimulate economic growth, pledging allegiance to a Reaganesque model of conservatism that has largely become the party’s orthodoxy.
